posts.content:
Taking the Hero’s Path on the way to a King's Crowning PvM/E (1-40) and PvP

Beowulf (Prince of Geats)
By Tyr Templar
Author’s Note: This build was first published in the ECB2 (NWN2) on May 23, 2008, and has been adapted for NWN1. It is inspired by the legendary Beowulf, Prince of Geats, from the old English poem (as translated by Nobel Laureate Seamus Heaney). This build is also the first of what is hoped to be a multi-character series inspired by Old Norse/Germanic Hero tales, which series Beowulf kicks off.

Grüss Gott, and may the legends of Beowulf live on ~ Tyr.
Concept: From out of the moor, Grendel, the monstrous troll, appeared from the mist and headed to the mead hall, hungry. He ripped open the door of the hall and entered to see the sleeping warriors, with only but one man standing. That man was Beowulf, a hero and Prince of the Geats. Beowulf watched on while Grendel reached out for an unlucky warrior and ate him. He reached next out for our hero, salivating, at which point Beowulf grabbed onto Grendel's clawed hand and held tight. Surprised at the strength of the mortal’s grip upon him, Grendel attempted to flee, but Beowulf held fast. Awakened, the warriors watched as the struggle between Beowulf and the murderous beast shook the mead-hall; they watched as Beowulf pulled Grendel’s arm clear of its socket, and they heard Grendel cry out in imminent defeat.

The warriors rejoiced: Beowulf, it was agreed by all, was a hero fit to become king.

Weapon Note: Longsword taken for theme-reasons, it being the closest NWN to the “Magic Ring Hilt” Sword made for Beowulf by a Giant in the story, and is a nice, all-around weapon (without giving away any spoilers, also what you want if looking to play through the OC). That said, if you are uninterested in theme-play/longsword, then consider the scimitar for its crit range.

*PvM/E—Note: While it is well-known that Beowulf pulled the arm (disarm) off of the evil monster Grendel, mortally wounding him in turn, if looking to PvM/E your Beowulf (since monsters claws cannot be disarmed), then feel free to swap out disarm and impr.disarm for IKD and Expertise instead.

**Note--Dev.Crit Note: Prefer a double weapon specialization instead of Dev.Crit? It is also well known that Beowulf’s blows were lethal, quick-killing sea monsters with devastating precision among other things (which NWN connotes Dev.Crit). That said, if not interested in Dev.Crit and/or it’s banned on your world, then why not pick up a second weapon specialization, such as the Heavy Flail (large, 2-handed bludgeon damage). If so, take: WF: Heavy Flail, WS: Heavy Flail and Impr.Crit Heavy Flail (instead of Cleave, Grt. Cleave, Grt.Fort) pre-epics, and EWF: Heavy Flail and EWS: Heavy Flail (instead of OC, DC) in epics, or otherwise select feats of your own choosing.

IV, Combat Vitals:
i) Devasating Critical (DC): 42. +3 Rage: 45, +2 TR (lowers enemy saves): 47
ii) Terrifying Rage (DC): 45 + (1d10): 46-55

iii) Attack Bonus and Damage
BAB: 30, AB (naked): 46, +3 Raging: 49
Mundane Longsword: 1-8 +18, +3 Rage, +5 PA (-5ab) (Crit: 17-20/x2) (Keen: 15-20/x2)

V. Defense Vitals:
AC (naked): 16, +8 plate, +3 shield: 27* (-2 raging, but offset by TR)
Note: add +5 if took expertise, or AC 32 (-5 ab expert.mode)

Other: Barbarian DR 2/- and Speed; Divine Wrath

VI. Skillpoints: 253*
Concentration 42(44, +3 Rage: 47), Discipline 43(55, +3 Rage: 58), Heal 4(3), Intimidate 43(45), Listen 43(42), Spellcraft 18(20), Tumble 21(21)

Players should feel free to adjust their Beowulf to suit their needs/environs, as always.

*Note--Divine Wrath: a once a day ability, that is available to Beowulf in case of “emergency” so to speak, just unlock with CHA (item, potion). When “pulled”, at 18 CoT levels, it will add +7 all-saves, +7 AB/+7 Damage (Divine-Based) and DR 10/+2 to the corresponding figures above (adjust accordingly).
